Award.AwardTitle: RI: Medium: Dynamical Coordination and Sequencing of Multifunctionality in Animals and Robots

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
How can intelligent control be created for autonomous robots that will allow them to respond flexibly and adaptively to changing environments? In the animal world, relatively simple animals such as soft-bodied invertebrates, are capable of coordinating their many possible movements, flexibly shifting and sequencing multiple behaviors as conditions change, and learning to alter their behavior based on experience. For robots, however, this remains a challenge, which is addressed in this project using a novel control architecture that can produce sensory driven or cyclic movements.

Traditional control architectures for robotics have three layers: high level deliberative planning, low-level reactive control, and an intermediate level for sequencing and simple decision-making. Creating intermediate level controllers for intelligent behavior is particularly challenging, and a major obstacle to progress in autonomous robotics. This problem will be addressed using a novel neural-inspired control architecture, stable heteroclinic channels (SHCs) that can flexibly and robustly orchestrate multiple degrees of freedom for multifunctionality, and can readily handle behavioral hierarchies, temporal decision-making, and learning. Their properties also allow them to incorporate some of the best aspects of the two traditional approaches to robotic control: finite state machines and central pattern generator (limit cycle) controllers. SHC-based dynamical architectures underlying multifunctionality will be analyzed in a soft-bodied animal that is tractable to experimentation, and principles from these neurobiological architectures will be used to implement multifunctional behavior in a novel hyper-redundant, soft-bodied robot platform.

There are many possible applications for adaptive, flexibly-controlled soft-bodied, or hyper-redundant, robots that are able to coordinate their many degrees of freedom in varying ways to accomplish multiple functions. A multifunctional worm-like robot could crawl through pipes of varying diameter and at any angle with respect to gravity and make sharp turns at intersections. A hollow hyper-redundant robot could inspect water mains from the inside, without interrupting water flow. Such a robot could be used for oil and gas pipeline inspections to avoid costly and environmentally disastrous leaks. Smaller versions could be developed for endoscopic diagnosis of the gastrointestinal tract. The proposed work will lead to a single controller framework that can robustly coordinate multiple coupled actuated mechanisms within a robot, and describe the sequencing of distinct behaviors in both animals and robots.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

Learning about the dynamics of cyclic behavior is important for developing robust intelligent control for robots and understanding neurobiological coordination in animals and humans. To better understand sensitivity to perturbations of cyclic behaviors in neurobiology, we modeled feeding in sea slugs with a mathematical concept called, Stable Heteroclinic Channels (SHCs). Compared with a standard limit cycle central pattern generator oscillator, we showed that this SHC model was dependent on sensory input for maintaining a fixed period. Our prediction that this is a good model for animals was confirmed by experiments in which the nervous system was isolated from all sensory feedback. A result is a multi-stable system that switches from a limit-cycle-like behavior to an SHC-like behavior and can demonstrate both robustness to perturbations and sensitivity.

To translate an SHC mathematical framework into tools that can be used for robotics, we created software for designing SHC cycles with predictable and controllable periods.   An SHC can be visualized as trajectory paths from the unstable manifold of one saddle point to the stable manifold of another saddle point.  As a result of our work, an SHC designer can specify mean period or sub-period, amplitude, stability, responsiveness, and variability in period or sub-period. To demonstrate the generality of control by SHCs, we built a software interface that permits SHC oscillators to be simulated on a microcontroller for robots.  The MATLAB software toolbox we used to implement this on several robots is available online.

This work on SHC dynamics was paired with an exploration of soft-body robot locomotion because both exemplify continuity, modularity, and responsiveness.  To explore the advantages of SHCs for control of worm-like locomotion, we developed a dynamic simulation of a worm robot. An insight from this simulation was that the limiting cost of transport (as measured by slip of anchoring segments) can be minimized by ensuring that segments between anchoring segments expand and retract at equal and opposite rates. In order to synchronize a worm robot’s many segments in response to sensory input, we used an SHC controller, which reduced the cost of transport by 40% through a narrowing tube. 

Worm robots were constructed that could crawl forward, turn and sense their environments. These soft robots demonstrated modular design, softness that allows them to conform to their environments, turning, scalability to smaller size, distributed sensing, and the value of a soft, stretchable, compliant fabric skin. These platforms are being used for exploring robust intelligent behaviors in confined spaces.

Publications:  14 journals, 25 reviewed conference papers, 21 abstracts/posters/non reviewed

Broader Impacts:

The project has contributed to both neurobiology and neuromechanics. Understanding how biological pattern generators can both be robust and flexible has been clarified by the theoretical and experimental results, and is likely to be broadly applicable to the analysis of other flexible, robust pattern generators in animals and in humans. At the same time, the project has clarified features of peristaltic locomotion that provide deeper insights into how soft-bodied animals move.

There are many possible applications for the work resulting from this project. A worm-like robot could crawl through pipes of varying diameter and at any angle with respect to gravity and make sharp turns at intersections. A hollow soft worm robot could inspect water mains and oil and gas pipelines from the inside, without interrupting flow while preventing disastrous leaks. Smaller versions could be used for endoscopic diagnosis of the gastrointestinal tract.

The project contributed to the development of infrastructure for science and engineering through outreach efforts to high school students, to undergraduates through courses on biological modeling and robotics, and interdisciplinary training and mentorship to graduate students and postdoctoral fellows who are now addressing problems at the intersection of neurobiology and robotics in their research. The Biorobotics Lab provided tours to more than 500 visitors each year. Soft robots developed throughout the duration of this project were demonstrated at Engineers Week banquets, the Great Lakes Science Center and Research ShowCASE, for a combined total of over 5000 people. Our soft-bodied robots will also be showcased on the TV show “Nature Knows Best” due to air in late November 2017. Area high school students had an opportunity to work on the project closely with undergraduate and graduate students. The project hosted a number of undergraduate researchers using SOURCE, REU and other research funds and some of them have gone to graduate school including a recent African American woman. This project has benefited from valuable contributions from 14 female students. In total, 5 high school students, 27 undergraduate students, 12 graduate students and 2 postdoctoral fellows have greatly contributed to this project. Thus far, 6 PhD and 3 M.S. students have graduated and 3 PhD students are nearing completion.
